lines.text: Well I'm not a scientist. But I know all things begin and end in eternity.
[last lines]
I think maybe Mr. Newton has had enough, don't you?
I think maybe, he has.
Ah.
We'd have probably done the same to you, if you'd come 'round our place.
You know Tommy, you're a freak. I don't mean that unkindly. I like freaks. And that's why I like you.
Ask me...
What?
The question you've been wanting to ask ever since we met.
Are you Lithuanian?

[grins]
I come from England.
Ah, that's not so terrible.
My father used to say "Oliver, when you get a gift horse, walk up to it, pat it, quiet the animal down and then using both hands force open it's jaws and have a damn good look in it's mouth."
I'd say that was good advice
Yes, but my father was always wrong!
What are they like, your children?
They're like children. Exactly like children...
I don't love you anymore.
And I don't love you.

Television. The strange thing about television is that it - doesn't *tell* you everything. It *shows* you everything about life on Earth, but the true mysteries remain. Perhaps it's in the nature of television. Just waves in space.
Mary Lou! Help me!
Can I help?
I'm sorry. I want to sell this ring.

[looks it over]
Where'd you get it from?
My wife gave it to me. You see it has initials.

[reads]
T.J.N. Do you have any I.D.?
I'm British, I have a passport.
[shows it to her]

[reads]
Thomas Jerome Newton. This is not a pawn shop, Mr. Newton.
I beg your pardon?
If you sell it to me now, you can't redeem it later.
I understand.
If I stay, I'll die.
What're you talking about? Take me with you, I'll see you don't die.
I can't stay.
[walks away from her]
You're an alien!
They're stuck! I'll never get them off.
My interest is energy - transference of energy.
What is this music Farnsworth keeps sending me? I don't like it.
Some big named composer.
I don't want it. I want something with singing on it.
If I had the copyright on the Bible, I wouldn't sell it to Random House.
First, we'll have a drink. Then I'll have a bath. And tomorrow - we'll go to church. Lord, I love gin.

[Mary-Lou starts the elevator]
I'll just walk.
It's five flights.
[Thomas leans against the wall and falls to the floor]
Should I stop it?
Just keep going.
Oh my God.
You put alcohol in my drink.
My life isn't secret, Mr. Farnsworth, but it is private.
Hello. You know, you're not at all like my father.
You know, you're not a bit like my father.
Well, I'm not a lecherous old man; but, you're a lecherous little girl!
But, no one would ever believe it!
Do you think I could have something to drink?
Are you sure you should drink?
I'd like a glass of...
Gin? A nice gin and tonic with four cubes of ice and a slice of lime. Hmm. How's that sound mister?
Just a glass of water.
Boy, you're really hooked on water, aren't you?
I really like you mister. What do you do? For a living, I mean?
Oh, I'm just visiting.
Oh, a traveler!
I can't go to church.
a meaning to life. I mean, when you look out at the sky at night, don't you feel that somewhere, out there, there's gotta be a God. There's gotta be.
They're so strange here, the trains.

[Talking to herself]
Damn cheap princess.
Are you married?
Yes.
I thought so. What's she like, your wife? Is she like me?
No.
I didn't think so. Well, I guess I'll do for now, won't I?

You see, Mr. Newton, I'm kind of a cliche. I'm the disillusioned scientist, that goes with the cynical writer, the alcoholic actor and the spaced-out spaceman. A man like you wouldn't understand a guy like me.
Per ardua ad astra... That's Latin.
Latin?
You must know that in England? The Royal Air Force, their motto.
Yes.
Per ardua ad astra. Through difficulties to the stars.
Oh, come on, Tommy. Don't go now. Give us another chance.
[whispers]
You won't find anyone else like me, you know. You won't find anyone who'd do for you like I've done for you.
Why'd you come here?
Where I come from, there's a terrible drought. We saw pictures of your planet on television. We saw the water. In fact, our word for your planet means - planet of water.
You watched it all on television?
What happens to you when you drink?
I see things.
Mmmm. I want it. I've been dreaming of it. Please.
This country's rich! We got - everything!

All I'm trying to say, Tommy, is that if you could just prove who you really are, you'd be *free*! Don't you understand, they don't understand you! The don't *believe* you. Believe me, they think you're one of *us*. They think you're a freak - or a fake. I know you're not. All you have to do is just prove it to 'em. Let 'em see you as you really are!
You're going to die like an animal. Just an animal - a stupid creature.

[Referring to Newton's phonograph record]
Who'd you make it for, then?
For my wife. She'll get to hear it one day - on the radio.
We hear most everything on the radio these days.
Don't you feel bitter about it - everything?
Bitter, no. We'd have probably treated you the same if you'd come over to our place.
I may not stay - sober anymore. But, I still have money.
